questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department due to the abrupt onset of right-sided weakness. She was watching TV when she started feeling right side numbness and had difficulty moving her right arm and leg. Medical history is unremarkable. Medications include oral contraceptives and ibuprofen for occasional migraines. She reports a 2-month history of dyspnea which she initially attributed to a viral illness she had prior. Her temperature is 38.0°C (100.2°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mmHg. On physical examination, strength is 5/5 on the left side and 2/5 on the right side. Touch and temperature sensations are diminished on the right side. Cardiac auscultation reveals a low pitch early diastolic sound heard most prominently on the left sternal border. Echocardiography is obtained and shown below:  



Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  

Histopathology examination of this patient’s finding will most likely show which of the following?

choices.text: Hamartomatous growth; polygonal cells with glycogen-laden vacuoles
Gelatinous material; cells immersed in glycosaminoglycans
Vegetations; strands of fibrin, neutrophils, and lymphocytes

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of dyspnea, low-grade fever, new onset of stroke along with the echocardiography findings, most likely has a cardiac myxoma.  

Cardiac myxomas are the most common primary cardiac neoplasm, accounting for 50% of all primary cardiac tumors. The majority of myxomas originate from the left atrium. Histologically, it is composed of gelatinous myxoma cells scattered within a mucopolysaccharide stroma. Macroscopically, they are often described as a pedunculated, “ball-valve” lesion. Patients frequently present with constitutional symptoms (e.g., weight loss, fever) that are thought to be related to the production of cytokines (e.g. interleukin-6) and growth factors by the tumor. Symptoms vary and often accompany a change of body position due to the pedunculated architecture, causing a "ball-valve" effect that obstructs blood flow from the left atrium to the left ventricle. The transient mitral valve obstruction can mimic mitral stenosis. Symptoms include dyspnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, dizziness, syncope, palpitations, chest pain, embolization, and sudden death. Systemic embolization occurs when fragments from the tumor enter the systemic circulation. On physical examination, early diastolic, low pitch sounds are often heard when the tumor is lodged into the mitral valve surface (“tumor plop”). Diagnosis is made by echocardiography and treatment involves resection.     

Option Analysis

❌ Hamartomatous growth; polygonal cells with glycogen-laden vacuoles:
Incorrect: These characteristics are consistent with a cardiac rhabdomyoma, the most common primary pediatric tumor of the heart. It develops almost exclusively in children, and the majority of cases are associated with tuberous sclerosis. It typically develops intramurally in the septum or the free wall of the left ventricle, where it may cause conduction abnormalities and obstruction, rather than embolization. This patient’s presentation and age favor another diagnosis.   
✅ Gelatinous material; cells immersed in glycosaminoglycans:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Benign growth; mature white adipocytes:
Incorrect: These characteristics are consistent with a lipoma, which can present at any age. The majority of lipomas originate from the subendocardial region and less commonly from the myocardial and subepicardial regions. Many are asymptomatic, but some obstruct flow or cause arrhythmias. Embolization is less likely.   
❌ Vascular channels; malignant cells:
Incorrect: These characteristics are consistent with angiosarcoma, an extremely rare cardiac tumor. Most originate from the right atrium, infiltrate the pericardium and cause right ventricular inflow tract obstruction, pericardial tamponade, and lung metastases. The tumor location and the rarity of cardiac angiosarcoma favor another diagnosis.   
❌ Vegetations; strands of fibrin, neutrophils, and lymphocytes:
Incorrect: These characteristics are consistent with Libman–Sacks endocarditis, a form of nonbacterial endocarditis that is often associated with systemic lupus erythematosus. The mitral valve is typically affected, and the vegetations occur on both sides of the valve. It can also be seen in advanced malignancy and inflammatory conditions such as antiphospholipid syndrome, rheumatoid arthritis, sepsis, and burns. Libman–Sacks lesions are often asymptomatic and rarely cause valve dysfunction and embolization. This patient was previously healthy and her echocardiography findings favor another diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man comes to the office due to the progressive growth of skin lesions that appear on his back. He first noticed them 6 months ago, and since then they have increased in number. He mentions that the lesions often bleed with minor trauma. He is worried that he might have cancer because his father died of skin cancer, but he cannot recall the type. He is a retired computer engineer and spends most of his time reading and playing with his grandchildren. Medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertriglyceridemia. Physical examination reveals multiple dome-shaped, dark-red lesions with some coagulated blood surrounding a few of them. Biopsy of the lesion is obtained and shown below.  



Reproduced from: Wikipedia

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has cherry hemangiomas, which are benign, mature proliferations of capillaries. His biopsy results show vascular tumors with abundant red blood cells, which helps to distinguish the lesions from other dermal proliferations (e.g. acrochordon).  

Cherry hemangiomas often occur as multiple lesions, typically on the trunk, and they tend to bleed with trauma. They are usually dark-red, purple, or blue-black, dome-shaped lesions, and they blanch with pressure. The pathogenesis is not completely understood. The diagnosis is based on the clinical appearance of the lesions. Treatment of cherry angiomas includes different topical interventions (e.g., cryotherapy, laser removal), and the decision to remove is based on whether the patient finds the lesions bothersome.  

Option Analysis

❌ Angiosarcoma:
Incorrect: Angiosarcomas are rare, aggressive, blood vessel malignancies which typically occur in the head, neck, and breast areas. The tumors are often difficult to resect due to bleeding risk and delays in diagnosis. Risk factors include sun exposure, radiation therapy, and chronic postmastectomy lymphedema. Hepatic angiosarcoma is associated with vinyl chloride and arsenic exposures. This patient has none of these risk factors, and the characteristics of his lesions favor another diagnosis.  
✅ Cherry hemangioma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Strawberry hemangioma:
Incorrect: Strawberry hemangiomas are benign tumors of the vascular endothelium. They are the most common childhood tumor, and they are characterized by an early growth phase and involution after the first year of life. This patient’s age and presentation favor another diagnosis.   
❌ Seborrheic keratoses:
Incorrect: Seborrheic keratoses are flat, pigmented squamous epithelial proliferation of immature keratinocytes. They are often described as having a “stuck on” appearance. Lesions can occur on the head, trunk, and extremities. They are the most common benign neoplasm seen in older individuals; however, rapid appearance of multiple seborrheic keratoses indicates possible GI adenocarcinoma (Leser-Trélat sign). This patient’s characteristic lesions and biopsy results favor another diagnosis.  
❌ Acrochordon :
Incorrect: Acrochordons, also known as skin tags, are an outgrowth of normal skin often seen in older individuals. They appear as pinkish, skin-colored, pedunculated lesions with narrow stalks. Similar to cherry hemangiomas, their number often increases with age. However, they typically appear in sites of friction, particularly the axilla, neck, inframammary, and inguinal regions. Diabetes, obesity and Crohn's disease (perianal) are contributing factors for developing the lesions. This patient’s characteristic lesions and biopsy results favor another diagnosis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the clinic due to the recent onset of pain in his left middle finger. He described the pain as sharp and paroxysmal. The patient works as a gardener, and he first noticed the pain after getting hit on the hand. Medical history is unremarkable, and he takes no medications. Examination of the skin and nails shows dystrophic nail and subungual bluish discoloration under the left middle fingernail bed. Applying pressure triggers exquisite pain. This patient’s lesion arises from a structure involved in which of the following physiologic roles?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has a glomus tumor, a benign neoplasm that arises from the modified smooth muscle cells of the glomus body. A glomus body (or glomus apparatus) is an element of the dermis involved in body temperature regulation. Glomus bodies are prevalent in the fingers and toes. Patients with glomus tumors typically present with nail dystrophy and a subungual pink/purple vascular nodule associated with cold sensitivity, paroxysmal pain (i.e. sudden painful attacks), and tenderness. Subungual glomus tumors are particularly painful. Glomus tumors of the fingers and toes can be seen in approximately 5% of patients with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) or can arise sporadically.  

The diagnosis is usually based upon the clinical appearance and symptoms, and treatment is surgical excision. However, definitive diagnosis can be made only by histopathologic examination. Histologically, glomus tumors are composed of glomus cells, vasculature, and smooth muscle cells.   

Option Analysis

✅ Thermoregulation :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Pigment production:
Incorrect: Melanocytes are cells of neural crest origin that are responsible for melanin production in the skin in response to sun exposure. An example of a lesion arising from melanocytes is melanoma. Acral lentiginous melanoma is a subtype of melanoma that arises on the palmar and plantar surfaces, including the nail bed. Although it can also cause nail dystrophy, it is usually seen as a longitudinal brown or black band in the fingernail. Additionally, exquisite pain with pressure is unlikely.   
❌ Forming the capillary wall:
Incorrect: The capillary walls are formed by endothelial cells. An example of a lesion arising from these cells is a cherry hemangioma, a benign capillary proliferation seen in older individuals. They are typically dark red, dome-shaped lesions that appear on the torso and increase with age.  
❌ Maintaining skin barrier and homeostasis:
Incorrect:  The skin barrier is mostly composed of the squamous cells (keratinocytes) of the epidermis, which are the cells responsible for maintaining skin homeostasis by providing a physical barrier from the environment. An example of a lesion arising from these cells is squamous cell carcinoma, which often occurs in sun-exposed areas. Subungual squamous cell carcinoma is rare and is not associated with exquisite pain with pressure.  
❌ Insulation of nerves:
Incorrect: Insulation of nerves is the role of Schwann cells, which compose the myelin nerve sheath of peripheral nerves. An example of lesions arising from these cells includes schwannomas, which typically occur along the peripheral nerve (e.g. vestibular schwannoma). Subungual schwannoma is rare.

questions.text: A 58-year-old Caucasian man comes to the office because of dull abdominal pain and nausea for the past 2 months. The pain is located at the right side of the abdomen, and the patient rates it 4/10 in intensity. The patient has worked as an engineer in a PVC pipe factory for the past 35 years. Medical history is relevant for hypertension, obesity, and recent travel to China. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows pale skin and conjunctiva, hepatomegaly, and shifting dullness to percussion. Abdominal computed tomography reveals a hypoattenuating, solitary mass with nodular enhancement in the liver. Immunostaining is positive for CD31. Serum alpha-fetoprotein is 8 ng/mL (normal value <10 ng/mL). Serology is negative for hepatitis B and C. Which of the following is the most likely cause for this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of chronic polyvinyl chloride exposure (PVC industry) and nonspecific abdominal pain likely has liver angiosarcoma. Angiosarcoma is a rare malignant vascular neoplasm of the endothelial-type cells that line vessel walls.  

The pathogenesis of angiosarcoma is characterized by a rapid and extensively infiltrating overgrowth of vascular epithelial cells. Common angiosarcoma locations include the liver, kidney, lung, and breast. In the liver, the tumor cells tend to grow along sinusoids and branches of the portal and hepatic veins. Immunostaining typically shows positivity for vascular markers, including ERG transcription factor, CD31, CD34, and factor VIII antigen. The most common cause of liver angiosarcoma is the prolonged exposure to vinyl chloride monomers (i.e., weatherstripping material, plastic pipes) and polyvinyl chloride (PVC). Other less common causes include arsenic, anabolic steroids, radiation, and thorium dioxide.  

The imaging modality of choice for diagnosing angiosarcoma will depend on the location. For liver angiosarcoma, the imaging modality of choice is MRI or enhanced CT scan. On CT scan, findings suggestive of angiosarcoma may include vascular invasion, nodular enhancement (common), and a hypoattenuating mass.      

Option Analysis

❌ Cholangiocarcinoma:
Incorrect: Cholangiocarcinoma is an adenocarcinoma arising from biliary epithelium that lines the bile ducts. It is associated with Clonorchis sinensis infection and primary sclerosing cholangitis. Abdominal ultrasound may demonstrate biliary duct dilatation, but small lesions are difficult to visualize. Immunohistochemically, the majority of cholangiocarcinomas are positive for cytokeratin (CK) 7 and CK19.  
❌ Hepatic adenoma  :
Incorrect: Hepatic adenomas are rare, benign liver tumors arising from hepatocytes. Oral contraceptives and steroids are commonly associated with hepatic adenomas. These tumors are hormone-induced, and thus they tend to regress if the patient stops the medication. The most common symptom is pain due to compression of adjacent structures, but they may result in life-threatening intra-abdominal bleeding. On ultrasound, hepatic adenomas typically present as a solitary, well-demarcated, heterogeneous mass.  
❌ Hepatocellular carcinoma:
Incorrect: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is the most common primary liver cancer. HCC is strongly associated with chronic HBV/HCV infections and alcoholic cirrhosis. Increased alpha-fetoprotein (>500 ng/mL) is seen in 70% of patients with HCC. In this case, the patient is negative for hepatitis B/C and has normal alpha-fetoprotein levels, making HCC unlikely.    
✅ Liver angiosarcoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Liver metastasis:
Incorrect: Liver metastasis is far more common than primary liver tumors. Primary tumors that tend to send metastasis to the liver include colon, stomach, and pancreas. Patients with liver metastases are either asymptomatic or present with abdominal pain and unintentional weight loss. On imaging, metastasis usually presents as multiple lesions rather than a solitary mass. In this case, the patient's medical history of polyvinyl chloride exposure favors liver angiosarcoma.

questions.text: A 27-year-old primigravid woman at 14 weeks gestation comes to the office due to the recent appearance of a sore on her lower lip. She first noticed it 2 weeks ago, and since then it has rapidly grown in size and became ulcerated. The patient has had consistent prenatal care and her medical history is unremarkable. She denies any trauma or recent illness. She works as a secretary in a large law firm. Physical examination shows a large pedunculated lesion on the lower lip with central ulceration and bleeding. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This previously healthy pregnant woman who is presenting with a rapidly growing vascular lesion most likely has pyogenic granuloma.

Pyogenic granuloma (PG), also known as lobular capillary hemangioma, is a benign vascular tumor of the skin or mucous membranes. It is characterized by rapid growth and a friable surface that tends to ulcerate and bleed. PG can occur at any age but are most commonly seen in children and young adults. It often appears after trauma or during pregnancy (granuloma gravidarum). The lesions may regress spontaneously (especially after pregnancy) or undergo fibrosis, but they often require surgical excision. On histology, the lesions demonstrate a proliferation of immature vessels similar to granulation tissue.    

 



Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons
Pyogenic granuloma of the skin  

Option Analysis

❌ Basal cell carcinoma:
Incorrect: Basal cell carcinoma typically presents as a slow-growing, waxy, pink, pearly nodule, commonly with telangiectasias and rolled borders. Surface crust or ulceration may also be present. It can be found in sun-exposed areas of the body and classically appears on the upper lip. On histology, blue cells with a palisading pattern are expected. Although biopsy is needed for confirmation, this patient’s lesion characteristics favor another diagnosis.    
❌ Squamous cell carcinoma:
Incorrect: Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) typically presents as a slow-growing lesion with a scaly hyperkeratotic surface. It commonly appears on the face, lower lip, ears, and hands. It is associated with excessive exposure to sunlight, immunosuppression, chronic wounds, and arsenic exposure. Although biopsy is needed for confirmation, this patient’s lesion characteristics and the absence of risk factors favor another diagnosis.   
❌ Herpes simplex virus:
Incorrect: Herpes labialis, also known as a cold sore, is an infection caused usually by HSV type 1 and less commonly type 2. Primary infection can be accompanied by fever, sore throat, enlarged lymph nodes and a painful vesicular sore on the lips. Recurrent infections are common and may be preceded by pain, burning, tingling, and pruritus prior to the appearance of the first vesicles. The rash usually heals within 10 days, but the virus remains dormant in the dorsal root of the trigeminal ganglion. This patient’s lesion characteristics favor another diagnosis.    
✅ Pyogenic granuloma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Bacillary angiomatosis:
Incorrect: Bacillary angiomatosis is a condition caused by Bartonella henselae or Bartonella quintana and usually occurs in immunocompromised patients (e.g. HIV). It is characterized by multiple vascular papules and nodules similar to pyogenic granulomas. On histology, lobular, vascular proliferation of vessels lined by endothelial cells as well as clusters of neutrophils and lymphocytes are expected. This patient is immunocompetent and has a single lesion, which makes this diagnosis very unlikely.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old man comes to his primary care provider regarding mouth discomfort and bleeding for the past several weeks. He noticed bleeding after brushing his teeth. The patient's medical history is notable for HIV infection, and he says that he has been poorly compliant with his antiretroviral medication. Physical examination shows an intraoral dark-brown lesion with an overlying plaque which is easily scraped. Biopsy of the lesion shows significant lymphocyte infiltration and the presence of spindle cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  



Reproduced from from: Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
The patient most likely has Kaposi sarcoma (KS). KS is a low-grade vascular tumor caused by human herpesvirus virus 8 (HSV-8), which is transmitted via sexual contact. Although KS can involve virtually any part of the body, cutaneous disease is the most common initial presentation. The lesions of KS are elliptical pink, red, purple, or brown, and they are often found on the lower extremities, face, oral mucosa, and genitalia. The lesions are not painful and do not produce necrosis of overlying skin.  

Diagnosis is based upon the characteristic appearance, but sometimes biopsy is required for confirmation. Histologic examination of the lesions will likely show whorls of spindle-shaped cells with lymphocytic infiltration and aberrant proliferation of small vessels. While this condition is most often associated with HIV infection and immunosuppressed individuals, it can also rarely occur elderly men of Mediterranean or Sub-Saharan African descent.  



Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons  

Option Analysis

❌ Bacillary angiomatosis:
 Incorrect: Bacillary angiomatosis is caused by Bartonella species, a gram-negative bacillus transmitted to humans, most commonly via scratch from an infected cat. Immunodeficient individuals may present with fever, fatigue, anorexia and characteristic vascular pedunculated skin lesions. Neutrophilic infiltrate, as opposed to this patient’s lymphocytic infiltrate, is found on biopsy.   
✅ Human herpesvirus infection  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Hairy leukoplakia:
Incorrect: Hairy leukoplakia is a benign squamous cell proliferation that presents as irregular, white, painless plaques on the lateral tongue. It is Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) mediated and typically occurs in immunodeficient individuals. In contrast to candidiasis thrush (scrapable), leukoplakia cannot be scraped off.   
❌ Human papillomavirus infection:
Incorrect: Human papillomavirus infections mostly cause no symptoms and resolve spontaneously. In some, they persist and result in warts or precancerous lesions. The precancerous lesions increase the risk of cancer of the cervix, vulva, vagina, penis, anus, mouth, or throat. Nearly all cervical cancers are due to strains HPV-16 and HPV-18. Papilloma lesions typically grow exophytically in finger-like fronds. Histopathologic examination typically shows hyperparakeratosis and koilocyte-like cells. This patient’s lesion favors another diagnosis.   
❌ Erythroplakia :
Incorrect: Erythroplakia is an uncommon oral lesion that carries a high risk of malignant transformation. It presents as a red, velvety, asymptomatic patch most commonly located on the tongue, floor of the mouth, and soft palate, and it is typically found in individuals who consume tobacco and alcohol. On histopathologic examination, erythroplakia shows dysplasia of variable grade, carcinoma in situ, or features of invasive squamous cell carcinoma.

questions.text: A 37-year-old primigravid woman at 22 weeks gestation comes to the clinic for her second-trimester fetal assessment. She has had full prenatal care, and her first-trimester assessment showed no abnormalities. This is her first pregnancy, and she is very excited about the upcoming birth of her daughter. Fetal ultrasound reveals increased nuchal translucency and a septated fluid collection that extends along the entire posterior length of the fetus. The doctor suspects a genetic abnormality. Which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient’s presentation?

choices.text: Gene deletion in chromosome 15 of paternal origin
Unbalanced Robertsonian translocation between chromosomes 14 and 21
Deletion of the short arm of chromosome 5

questions.solution:
A female fetus with increased nuchal translucency and septated fluid collection that extends along the entire posterior side of the fetus is consistent with a cystic hygroma seen in Turner syndrome.  

Turner syndrome, seen only in females, is caused by loss of the X chromosome due to nondisjunction during meiosis or mitosis (45, XO). The condition is characterized by short stature, ovarian dysgenesis, shield chest, bicuspid aortic valve, coarctation of the aorta, horseshoe kidney, high-arched palate, shortened 4th metacarpals, and lymphatic defects.  

Turner syndrome is associated with lymphatic dysplasia, and individuals with this condition often present with a webbed neck, cystic hygroma, and lymphedema of the hand and feet. Cystic hygroma, also known as cystic lymphangioma, is a benign congenital lymphatic malformation composed of small cavities, typically found in the posterior triangle of the neck. After birth, infants with cystic hygroma should be monitored for airway obstruction. Needle drainage may be used to reduce the volume of the cystic hygroma to prevent facial deformities and airway obstruction.    



Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons



Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Option Analysis

❌ Gene deletion in chromosome 15 of paternal origin:
Incorrect: A gene deletion in chromosome 15 of paternal origin is the pathogenesis behind Prader-Willi syndrome. Infants born with this condition typically present with hyperphagia, obesity, intellectual disability, hypogonadism, and hypotonia. It is not associated with increased nuchal translucency or fluid collections in the posterior side of the fetus.  
❌ Unbalanced Robertsonian translocation between chromosomes 14 and 21  :
Incorrect: Unbalanced Robertsonian translocations between chromosomes 14 and 21 are responsible for up to 4% of the cases of Down syndrome. Most cases are due to meiotic nondisjunction. Infants born with Down syndrome typically present with intellectual disability, flat facies, prominent epicanthal folds, single palmar crease, increased gap between 1st and 2nd toes, duodenal atresia, Hirschsprung disease, and congenital heart disease (eg, atrioventricular septal defect). Although Down syndrome is the most common aneuploidy associated with increased nuchal translucency, it typically presents in the first trimester, and it is not associated with a septated fluid collection that extends along the entire fetus.   
❌ Meiotic nondisjunction of chromosome 18:
Incorrect: Meiotic nondisjunction of chromosome 18 is the cause of Edwards syndrome (trisomy 18). Infants born with this condition typically present with intellectual disability, prominent occiput, rocker-bottom feet, clenched fists, low-set ears, micrognathia (small jaw), congenital heart disease, and omphalocele. Although increased nuchal translucency can occur in Edwards syndrome, septated fluid collection along the entire fetus favors another diagnosis.   
✅ Loss of paternal chromosome X :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Deletion of the short arm of chromosome 5:
Incorrect: Deletion of the short arm of chromosome 5 is the cause of Cri-du-chat syndrome.  Infants born with this condition typically present with moderate to severe intellectual disability, microcephaly, high-pitched crying, epicanthal folds, and cardiac abnormalities (VSD). It is not associated with increased nuchal translucency on ultrasound.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with HIV comes to the clinic due to the recent appearance of skin nodules and progressive fatigue and anorexia for the past 2 months. She recently moved to Ohio and started working in a pet store. She is currently not taking antiretroviral therapy, and her recent CD4 count one month ago was 80 cells/mm3. Her temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 125/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows multiple small red-purple papules, some of which are pedunculated and some bleed. Histopathology of one of the lesions shows vascular proliferation with some clusters of neutrophils and lymphocytes. Which of the following is the most likely pathogen responsible for this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient, who is presenting with fever, fatigue, anorexia and characteristic skin lesions, most likely has bacillary angiomatosis.  

Bacillary angiomatosis is caused by Bartonella species, a fastidious, slow-growing, gram-negative bacillus. The natural reservoir is domestic cats and is transmitted to humans via scratch, bite, or exposure to cat feces/fleas. Cat-scratch disease (CSD) usually affects immunocompetent children and presents as regional limited lymphadenopathy/lymphadenitis. Immunodeficient individuals, however, are at risk for developing disseminated bacillary angiomatosis which usually occurs when CD4 count is less than 100 cells/mm3.    

Patients with bacillary angiomatosis often present with constitutional symptoms, including fever, chills, malaise, headache, anorexia, weight loss and unique vascular lesions. The skin is the most affected organ, but the lesions can occur throughout the body (e.g., bone, lymph nodes, GI). The lesions may start as red to purple papules which gradually expand into pedunculated lesions or nodules that become friable and bleed. Biopsy shows vascular proliferation with clusters of neutrophils and lymphocytes infiltrating. Diagnosis is challenging and usually requires a combination of tests including culture, PCR, biopsy, and staining with Warthin-Starry silver staining. Treatment consists of prolonged courses of either erythromycin or doxycycline.  

Option Analysis

❌ Blastomycosis dermatitis:
Incorrect: Blastomycosis dermatitis is a systemic pyogranulomatous infection caused by inhalation of the spores of the dimorphic fungus, which is prevalent in North America. Pulmonary involvement is the most common manifestation, and patients may present with acute or chronic pneumonia. Skin involvement is also common, and present as gray to violet, verrucous skin lesions with an irregular border that may mimic squamous cell carcinoma. Biopsy from the margins typically shows broad-based budding organisms on microscopy. This patient’s characteristic nodules, biopsy results and the absence of pulmonary involvement favor another diagnosis.   
❌ Human herpesvirus 8 :
Incorrect: Kaposi sarcoma (KS) is an angioproliferative disorder caused by infection with human herpesvirus 8 (HSV-8), often seen in immunocompromised patients. KS can involve virtually any site in the body, however, cutaneous disease is most common. The lesions of KS can be pink, red, purple, or brown, and they tend to be elliptical, not painful or pruritic, and without necrosis. There are generally no associated constitutional symptoms. Additionally, histopathology analysis in KS will likely show whorls of spindle-shaped cells with lymphocytic infiltration, not neutrophilic infiltration, as well as proliferation of small vessels.  
✅ Bartonella henselae :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Yersinia pestis:
Incorrect: Yersinia pestis is a zoonotic infection that causes plague. It is transmitted by bites from rodent fleas, scratches or bites from infected domestic cats, and inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected animals. The most common manifestation is acute febrile lymphadenitis (bubonic plague). It is characterized by the acute onset of fever, chills, weakness, and headache, followed by intense pain and swollen lymphadenopathy. Skin lesions may appear and include eschars, pustules, or lesions resembling ecthyma gangrenosum. This patient’s presentation favors another diagnosis.  
❌ Rickettsia rickettsii  :
Incorrect: Rickettsia rickettsii is a gram-negative, obligate intracellular bacterium that causes Rocky Mountain spotted fever, a tick-borne disease (Dermacentor dog tick). Patients often present with non-specific symptoms such as fever, headache, malaise, myalgias, and arthralgias followed by blanching erythematous rash with macules that later become petechial. This patient’s presentation favors another diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old man presents to the emergency department with status epilepticus. Per paramedics, the patient was found seizing in a nearby park. His only belongings are a wallet and an identification card. The patient’s past medical history reveals polysubstance use, depression, hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 107/min, respirations are 21/min, blood pressure is 196/62 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 91% on room air. During the physical examination, the patient is actively seizing. A white powder is noted in the patient’s bilateral nares. Subsequently, he is given 2 mg of intravenous lorazepam, which terminates the seizure activity. An electrocardiogram is obtained and demonstrated below. Which of the following medications is contraindicated in treating this patient’s clinical condition?
 

 Image reproduced from Wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents in status epilepticus with evidence of recent cocaine use. His electrocardiogram demonstrates inferolateral ST-depressions, which concern myocardial ischemia. In this clinical setting, the administration of β-blockers is contraindicated due to the potential for unopposed ɑ-adrenergic stimulation and further exacerbation of coronary vasospasm.

β-blockers, including medications such as metoprolol, carvedilol, atenolol, and esmolol, are frequently used to treat hypertensive emergencies, supraventricular tachycardias, and heart failure. However, β-blocker administration must be carefully considered when evidence of cardiac ischemia and associated cocaine use. This precaution is due to theoretical concerns of coronary artery vasoconstriction and systemic hypertension secondary to unopposed α-adrenergic stimulation.

Care must also be taken when administering β-blocking medications to patients with asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) since β2-blockade on respiratory tract smooth muscles can lead to bronchoconstriction. Additional caution should be taken when administering these medications to patients with cardiovascular instability involving bradycardia or hypotension, as β-blockers can worsen these symptoms and potentially lead to heart block or heart failure.  

Option Analysis

✅ Metoprolol:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Nitroglycerin:
Incorrect: This patient has markedly elevated blood pressures and an electrocardiogram demonstrating inferolateral ST-depressions, suggestive of myocardial ischemia. Nitroglycerin is a potent vasodilator that can manage hypertensive emergencies, acute coronary syndromes, and acute congestive heart failure.  
❌ Phentolamine:
Incorrect: Phentolamine is a pure α-antagonist. The medication is often used to treat demand ischemia and hypertensive emergency secondary to cocaine ingestion.  
❌ Diazepam:
Incorrect: Diazepam is an appropriate medication to administer to this patient given this patient’s recent seizure and concern for an adrenergic surge.  
❌ Aspirin:
Incorrect: This patient has markedly elevated blood pressures and an electrocardiogram demonstrating inferolateral ST-depressions, suggestive of myocardial ischemia. There are no factors in this patient’s history that would preclude aspirin administration.
